data.title: Ringo Starr's 77th birthday: Facts about the Beatles drummer who inspired generations
data.meta_description: 10 interesting facts on the "fab-four" Ringo Starr.
data.text:
The lyricist of the Beatles' song 'Don't Pass Me By' and 'Octopus's Garden', Richard Starkey was born on July 7, 1940. Better known as Ringo Starr, the drummer was a singer, actor and songwriter.

Did you know that he was nicknamed 'Ringo' because of his habit of wearing numerous rings? Read on to know more about him!

advertisement

On Ringo Starr's 77th birthday today, here are some interesting facts on him:

Much of Starr's childhood was spent in hospitals. He missed so much of school that by the time he turned 15, he could barely read and write

Ringo quit school when he was only 15 to work for the British Railways

Ringo had a different style of drumming. He was a left handed drummer but played a right handed drum kit

Ringo provided the voice for the narrator Mr. Conductor in the TV series, Thomas The Tank Engine

Ringo wasn't a fan of retakes. When it came to recording, he always preferred getting the drums recorded in one take

Starr, at one point, had two number one hits: 'Photograph' and 'You're Sixteen'

The member of "fab-four" was asked to join the Beatles by Lennon himself. Immediately after joining The Beatles, Ringo shaved off his beard and re-styled his hair

After doing extremely good with the band, McCartney formally announced in April 1970 that Ringo had quit the Beatles

His first album in his solo career was Sentimental Journey (1970)

Ringo received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and also received the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award for his work with the Beatles.
